title: Cases and Fines for Fly Tipping

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please could you provide me with a breakdown by the different areas/wards of Sheffield for the following:
- the number of reported fly tipping instances
- the number of prosecutions
- the total raised from fines/penalties
Please can you provide this for the years 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023.
Yours faithfully,
Abu Yusuf

Dear Abu Yusuf
Thank you for your email of 17 May 2024 requesting an internal review
because we have failed to complete a response to you about flytipping.
Your request was dated 24 March 2024, and the legal deadline was 24/04/24.
We made a partial response to you on 24 April 2024 with information from
our Highways Maintenance Service, telling you that we would provide the
rest of the information by 7 May 2024.
Our services did reply on 25 and 26 April to our FOI Team but we closed
your request in error on 26 April 2024 and therefore did not remember that
there was outstanding data to provide you.
Under the EIR, we have a duty to inform you whether we hold the requested
information and, if so, to communicate the information to you ‘as soon as
possible, and no later than 20 working days after the date of receipt of
the request.’ [Regulation 5(2)] We are in breach of this regulation.
We uphold your complaint, and sincerely apologise for our omission.
The outstanding information you requested is:
1. The following data has been extracted from our Confirm database for all
fly tipping enquiries attached to Sheffield Wards, relating to our Parks
and Countryside service:

2. We are attaching a report with the breakdown of area for reports of
fly-tipping from our Environmental Protection Service. By postcode was the
only way the system would allow, and some of the data isn’t complete due
to addresses not being fully verified at the time.
We are unable to do the breakdown by ward with Fixed Penalty Notices and
fines as that is a separate part of the system, and we only log the
address of the person who is fined not the location of the fly-tipping. To
do otherwise, would require searching through all 660 records and logging
manually which could take between 2-5 mins per record depending on how the
information is presented. Under Regulation 12(4)(b) of the Environmental
Information Regulations 2004 we think this would be manifestly
unreasonable as it could take up to 55 hours.
Regulation 12(4)(b) is subject to a public interest test. Factors in
favour of disclosure are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is not in the public interest to spend such a large amount of officer time
on providing this information, as this would come at a large cost to the
council and would divert officers from being able to carry out other work.
On balance, the council believes that the public interest lies in
maintaining the exception.
We would be able to provide a breakdown of the postal area of those fined.
If you are still dissatisfied with the handling of your request, you can

Dear FOI,
If you look at my original request, I asked for a summary based on each Ward. You have sent me information based on different services, which I did not ask for. How many different services are there for which fly-tipping falls under and what are the names of these services? You said you sent me information based on the Highways Maintenance Service originally but the latest information (which you said was from your Environmental Protection Service) has the same data as the original re: FPN's and Fines. Can you clarify why these are the same or have you made an error in providing this information to me?
I disagree with your conclusion re: not being able to disclose the information of the FPN's and Fines by Ward. This is extremely important to disclose and is much needed for openness and transparency. This is in the public interest and withholding this information goes against this. Fly-tipping in Sheffield and around the UK is a major public health concern and so I would ask that you reconsider this decision and provide the requested information. Providing the postcode of those fined is not the same as fines related to the location of the fly-tipping offences, but please can you send this anyway.
Yours sincerely,
N. Hussain
